void LinearClassifier::classify ( const std::list< Array< double > > &  vectorsA,
std::list< unsigned > &  classNumsA 
) [inline]

The vectors in list "vectorsA" are classified.

Similar to method classify(const Array< double >& v), but here not one vector, but several vectors, that are stored in a list, are classified. The resulting class numbers are also stored in a list.

Parameters:
vectorsA List of vectors, that will be classified.
classNumsA List of resulting class numbers.
Returns:
none
Author:
M. Kreutz

unsigned LinearClassifier::classify ( const Array< double > &  v  ) 

Classifies vector "v".

Based on the characteristics stored in vector v, the trained classificator will assign the individual with these characteristics to a specific class.

Parameters:
v the vector that will be classified.
Returns:
the number of the class to which the classificator has assigned the vector.

void LinearClassifier::leaveOneOut ( const std::list< Array< double > > &  vectorsA,
const std::list< unsigned > &  classNumsA,
std::list< unsigned > &  resultNumsA 
) [inline]

Performs a "leaving-one-out" test for all vectors in the list "vectorsA".

Similar to method leaveOneOut(const Array< double >& v,unsigned m) but here all vectors in the list vectorsA are used. The predefined class numbers and the results of the classifications are also saved in lists.

Parameters:
vectorsA the list of vectors for which the test will be performed
classNumsA the list of classes, the vectors in vectorsA belong to
resultNumsA the list of results of the classification for the vectors in vectorsA
Returns:
none

Definition at line 623 of file LinearClassifier.cpp.

unsigned LinearClassifier::leaveOneOut ( const Array< double > &  v,
unsigned  m 
)

Performs a "leaving-one-out" test with vector "v" taken out of the training set.

A leaving-one-out test is a special case of cross validation and used for a realistic evaluation of the classificator. For this evaluation, vector v is taken out of the training set and the classificator is updated. Then vector v is used as test vector for the new classificator and the result of this classification is returned. Last, the vector is added to the training set again. To evaluate the error rate of a classificator you must perform the leaving-one-out test for all possible vectors in the training set, i.e. having vectors in the training set, the error is calculated by:

Here is the vector, that is taken out of the training set, is the class belongs to and is the result of the classification of vector for the classificator based on the training set .

Parameters:
v vector, that is taken out of the training set
m the class to which v belongs
Returns:
the class assigned to v by the classificator based on the training set without v
Exceptions:
check_exception the type of the exception will be "size mismatch" and indicates that v is not one-dimensional or that its size is wrong or that m is no valid class number or was not used before
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
Examples:
linearClassifier_test.cpp.

void LinearClassifier::train ( const std::list< Array< double > > &  vectorsA,
const std::list< unsigned > &  classNumsA 
) [inline]

The vectors in list "vectorsA" are used for training the classificator.

Similar to method train(const Array< double >& v,unsigned m), but here not one vector, but several vectors, that are stored in a list, are used for training. The class numbers are also stored in a list.

Parameters:
vectorsA List of training vectors.
classNumsA List of class numbers that correspond to the training vectors in vectorsA. classNumsA(i) is the number of the class, training vector vectorsA(i) belongs to.
Returns:
none

Definition at line 320 of file LinearClassifier.cpp.

void LinearClassifier::train ( const Array< double > &  v,
unsigned  m 
)

Vector "v" is used for training the classificator.

Vector v that contains the characteristics of one individual is used for the training of the classification function. This original data with the class it is assigned to is given to modify the classificator.
In this method only internal variables from which the classificator is evaluated are calculated. The classificator itself is calculated by method update. This separation of the calculation has the sense of increasing the calculation time when the training is called different times. Then, the classificator will only be calculated once at the end of the training instead of each time when the train method will be called.

Parameters:
v the training vector
m the number of the class the individual belongs to
Returns:
none
Exceptions:
check_exception the type of the exception will be "size mismatch" and indicates that v is not one-dimensional
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
update
Examples:
linearClassifier_test.cpp.

Definition at line 192 of file LinearClassifier.cpp.

Referenced by train().

void LinearClassifier::update (  ) 

Updates the classificator.

Here the current classificator is calculated by using the internal variables that were changed before.
This update is performed automatically by the classify methods when a change of the internal variables has taken place before, so you can be sure, that always the most current classificator is used.

Returns:
none
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
classify, train

Member Data Documentation

Array< unsigned > LinearClassifier::classAbsM [protected]

Hashtable.

The classes are saved here in the order they become known to the training method at run time.
classAbsM[ i ] will return the "absolute number" of the the i-th introduced class.
This is the opposite hashtable to classRelM.

Definition at line 367 of file LinearClassifier.h.

Referenced by update().

Array< unsigned > LinearClassifier::classRelM [protected]

Hashtable.

The classes are saved in the order they become known to the training method at run time. This hashtable maps the "absolute number" of the classes to the "relative number" under which they were saved.
classRelM[ i ] will return the relative number of class no. i, i.e. the index under which it is saved. This index then can be used to access data about this class which is saved in other structures under this index.
This is the opposite hashtable to classAbsM.

unsigned LinearClassifier::dimM [protected]

The number of predefined attributes used for the classification of each individual.

Because of the fact that training vectors enumerate the characteristics of individuals refering to the attributes, the dimension of each vector must be equal to the value of "dimM".

Definition at line 372 of file LinearClassifier.h.

Referenced by update().

unsigned LinearClassifier::usedClassesM [protected]

When a training vector belongs to a class that is unknown then space not only for this but for several classes is added to the existing one to speed up the whole training process.

To keep track of the space that is really used, "usedClassesM" saves the number of classes that are used.
